data: Social impact At Johnson & Johnson, we believe health is everything. Our strength in healthcare innovation empowers us to build a world where complex diseases are prevented, treated and cured, where treatments are smarter and less invasive, and solutions are personal. Through our expertise in Innovative Medicine and MedTech, we are uniquely positioned to innovate across the full spectrum of healthcare solutions today to deliver the breakthroughs of tomorrow and profoundly impact health for humanity. We seek to provide solutions for some of the world’s most pressing global public health challenges and work collectively—within our walls and externally with our partners—to advance better health for all. At Johnson & Johnson, we work to improve access and affordability, create healthier communities, and put a healthy mind, body and environment within reach. J&J CareCommunity J&J CareCommunity, a global social impact platform from Johnson & Johnson, champions nurses and community health workers to advance access to quality care around the world. Learn more Global health equity We are closing the gap between communities and care by enabling access to our medicines and technologies, championing nurses and health workers and working together with community-based organizations. Learn more J&J Impact Ventures Impact Ventures is an investment fund within J&J Foundation, supporting a global portfolio of early-stage companies transforming access to quality and affordable healthcare. Learn more Church Hill Medical Mission brings essential medical care to rural communities in Tennessee hard-hit by Hurricane Helene. Many storm survivors lost vehicles in the storm and don’t have transportation. The clinic provides care out of the back of a Subaru but plans to use emergency funding from Americares to purchase an all-terrain vehicle that will allow their volunteers to access hard-to-reach communities, including migrant workers. Church Hill medical volunteers also administer tetanus vaccinations and given out hygiene kits donated by Americares. Church Hill Medical Mission Clinic Director Kathy Christian (right) and Americares President and CEO Christine Squires (left) with hygiene kits donated by Americares.
